awd_titl_txt: Scanned-probe Characterization of Charge Generation, Recombination, and Motion in Organic Semiconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
Sunlight represents a limitless source of clean energy.  How can we provide everyone with a cheap way to capture and use the sun's energy to run their appliances and vehicles?  Rooftop silicon-based photovoltaic cells already exist for converting sunlight into electricity; however, these cells are expensive to manufacture and install.  This project's goal is to study solar cells made from plastics and organic molecules, which could allow solar cells to be as thin and inexpensive as a coat of paint.  Plastic/organic solar-cell materials have been studied for a long time, but how these materials convert light into electricity at the molecular level remains poorly understood.  To better understand these materials we are developing a microscope capable of watching charge move at the molecular level on the timescale of one nanosecond (one billionth of a second) or faster.  Such a microscope would give us a new way to study molecular-level processes ranging from photosynthesis to industrially important chemical reactions taking place at a metal surface.   The researchers funded by this project are using their knowledge of scientific instrumentation and computer programming to develop experiments introducing middle and high school students to topics ranging from the physics of music to the principles of electrochemistry.

Technical Abstract:
The goal of this project is to test molecular design rules thought to govern how light is converted into electricity in thin-film solar cells made from electron-accepting and electron-donating molecules, so-called donor-acceptor blends.   Localized measurements of charge recombination dynamics and charge mobility are carried out on donor-acceptor blends prepared from molecules with systematically varied energy levels and background charge density to support or refute theories describing how charge is generated from sunlight in these blends.  To enable these studies, scanned-probe-microscope measurements are developed capable of determining, with nanosecond temporal resolution and nanometer spatial resolution, the free charge yield and subsequent recombination dynamics in a thin film of a donor-acceptor blend following the application of a nanosecond-duration pulse of light.  A separate set of scanned-probe measurements are developed for inferring the local charge mobility from measurements of near-surface electric field fluctuations.   The tools created during this project are expected to ultimately have broad applications in studying industrially important processes like photocatalysis and electrocatalysis and in naturally important processes like photosynthesis.  The researchers funded by this research are using their knowledge of scientific instrumentation and computer programming to develop experiments introducing middle and high school students to topics ranging from the physics of music to the principles of electrochemistry.

por.por_cntn:
In solar cell materials light is absorbed, creating energetic mobile charges. These mobile charges lead to current and voltage that can be used to power electrical devices. Solar cell materials made out of plastics are especially interesting because they can be fabricated at high speed and low cost. A major unexplained feature of plastic solar cells is that the energetic mobile charges take far longer than expected to relax. To exploit this feature, we want to understand why the charges behave this way so we can make a more efficient plastic solar cell.

 In these materials the charges typically take between one millionth and one billionth of second to relax. We had invented a scanning electric-force microscope that could take time-lapse images of the charges relaxing. This microscope could see features as small as a few hundred atoms across. In this grant we used the microscope to study charge generation and relaxation in plastic solar cells and a competing low-cost material, lead-halide perovskite semiconductors.

These studies led to a number of surprising discoveries. In lead-halide perovskite semiconductors, we found that most of the light-induced mobile charge remains excited and mobile for millions of times longer than expected. We hypothesize that light in this semiconductor is knocking atoms loose from their usual positions, creating mobile ions and vacancies that cause light-induced electrical conductivity to persist for 10s to 100s of seconds before the atoms relax back into place. This persistent conductivity observation could explain why perovskite solar-cell materials have stability problems. We found that the persistent conductivity was very sensitive to the material on which the perovskite was grown. A beneficial discovery was that the persistent conductivity could be largely eliminated by forming a layered, two-dimensional perovskite material. 

The perovskite samples gave other interesting microscope signals, such as exhibiting a friction that increased and then decreased as the light intensity was raised. Understanding this extremely surprising behavior led us to develop a new mathematical description of the scanning electric-force microscope. This description makes it possible to straightforwardly infer a sample's electrical conductivity from the microscope signals for the first time, and also shows us how to follow changes in both capacitance and resistance on the timescale of billionths of a second using the microscope. With this new understanding in place, we returned to studying plastic solar cells. We were surprised to find that shining light on these materials primarily changes the sample resistance and not the capacitance, as is widely assumed. With this understanding in place, we can now properly design experiments to image charge relaxation in plastic solar cells.

We anticipate this work having a number of broader impacts. This project led to our creation of an open-source software package, FreqDemod, for analyzing and plotting the time-dependent frequency and amplitude of a sinusoidally oscillating signal. Our software has been used by medical researchers developing rapid diagnoses of strokes and high-school teachers developing physics-of-sound experiments. The young researchers trained on this project have unique insights into imaging charge at the atomic scale and determining how charge moves through complicated, technologically important materials like plastic solar cells and batteries. Understanding and manipulating persistent photo-induced conductivity in perovskite semiconductors could lead to new ways to perform computations, make more stable solar cell devices, and produce low-cost perovskite transistors. Finally, the scanning electric-force microscope is widely used in the solar-cell and semiconductor manufacturing industries. Our new mathematical description of the microscope will give rise to more meaningful measurements and therefore faster and more reliable manufacturing.
